All generations used a 1.8-inch (46 mm) hard drive for storage. The "classic" suffix was formally introduced with the rollout of the sixth-generation iPod on September 5, 2007. Prior to this, all iPod Classic models were simply referred to as iPods; the first iPod released in 2001 was part of this line that would be called "Classic".

document: Google Glass, developed by Google's X division, is a brand of smart glasses that aims to produce a ubiquitous computer experience. These glasses offer wearers a head-up display, allowing them to receive and view information effortlessly. By using natural language voice commands, users can communicate with the Internet, making for a hands-free and convenient experience. Initially released as a prototype to "Glass Explorers" in the US in 2013, Google Glass later became available to the general public in 2014. Notably, it is equipped with a 5-megapixel camera, capable of capturing high-quality still images and 720p video.
noref_document: Google Glass is a wearable technology developed by the search engine giant Google. It takes the form of smart glasses that incorporate augmented reality, allowing users to access information hands-free and interact with the digital world seamlessly. The glasses feature a small transparent display located above the right eye, providing users with notifications, maps, and other visual information in their line of sight. With voice commands and touch gestures, users can take photos, record videos, browse the internet, send messages, and even make video calls. Although the initial version of Google Glass faced various obstacles and was eventually discontinued, it played a significant role in advancing the development of smart glasses and demonstrated the potential of wearable technology in everyday life.
summary: Google Glass, or simply Glass, is a brand of smart glasses developed and sold by Google. It was developed by X (previously Google X), with the mission of producing a ubiquitous computer. Google Glass displays information to the wearer using a head-up display. Wearers communicate with the Internet via natural language voice commands.Google started selling a prototype of Google Glass to qualified "Glass Explorers" in the US on April 15, 2013, for a limited period for $1,500, before it became available to the public on May 15, 2014. It had an integral 5 megapixel still/720p video camera.

document: Kinect, developed by Microsoft, is a line of motion sensing devices that revolutionized the gaming industry when it was first released in 2010. Unlike its competitors, Kinect does not require physical controllers, making it a standout choice for gamers. Equipped with RGB cameras, infrared projectors, and detectors, Kinect calculates depth using structured light or time of flight calculations. This allows for real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, enabling users to interact with games using their own bodies. In addition, Kinect includes microphones for speech recognition and voice control, enhancing the immersive gaming experience. Initially introduced as a peripheral for the Xbox 360 under the codename "Project Natal," Kinect has since gained popularity and expanded to be implemented in various fields beyond gaming.
noref_document: Kinect is a motion sensing input device developed by Microsoft for the Xbox 360 video game console. Released in 2010, Kinect revolutionized the way users interacted with their gaming consoles by enabling them to control games using movements and gestures. Unlike traditional gaming controllers, Kinect uses an array of sensors to capture and track a player's body movements, allowing for a more immersive and intuitive gaming experience. In addition to gaming, Kinect also found applications in various fields such as healthcare, education, and robotics, where its motion tracking capabilities were used for gesture-based controls and motion analysis.
summary:
Kinect is a line of motion sensing input devices produced by Microsoft and first released in 2010. The devices generally contain RGB cameras, and infrared projectors and detectors that map depth through either structured light or time of flight calculations, which can in turn be used to perform real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, among other capabilities. They also contain microphones that can be used for speech recognition and voice control.
Kinect was originally developed as a motion controller peripheral for Xbox video game consoles, distinguished from competitors (such as Nintendo's Wii Remote and Sony's PlayStation Move) by not requiring physical controllers. The first-generation Kinect was based on technology from Israeli company PrimeSense, and unveiled at E3 2009 as a peripheral for Xbox 360 codenamed "Project Natal".

The devices generally contain RGB cameras, and infrared projectors and detectors that map depth through either structured light or time of flight calculations, which can in turn be used to perform real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, among other capabilities. They also contain microphones that can be used for speech recognition and voice control.
Kinect was originally developed as a motion controller peripheral for Xbox video game consoles, distinguished from competitors (such as Nintendo's Wii Remote and Sony's PlayStation Move) by not requiring physical controllers. The first-generation Kinect was based on technology from Israeli company PrimeSense, and unveiled at E3 2009 as a peripheral for Xbox 360 codenamed "Project Natal".

document: Kinect, developed by Microsoft, is a line of motion sensing devices that revolutionized the gaming industry when it was first released in 2010. Unlike its competitors, Kinect does not require physical controllers, making it a standout choice for gamers. Equipped with RGB cameras, infrared projectors, and detectors, Kinect calculates depth using structured light or time of flight calculations. This allows for real-time gesture recognition and body skeletal detection, enabling users to interact with games using their own bodies. In addition, Kinect includes microphones for speech recognition and voice control, enhancing the immersive gaming experience. Initially introduced as a peripheral for the Xbox 360 under the codename "Project Natal," Kinect has since gained popularity and expanded to be implemented in various fields beyond gaming.
noref_document: Kinect is a motion sensing input device developed by Microsoft for the Xbox 360 video game console. Released in 2010, Kinect revolutionized the way users interacted with their gaming consoles by enabling them to control games using movements and gestures. Unlike traditional gaming controllers, Kinect uses an array of sensors to capture and track a player's body movements, allowing for a more immersive and intuitive gaming experience. In addition to gaming, Kinect also found applications in various fields such as healthcare, education, and robotics, where its motion tracking capabilities were used for gesture-based controls and motion analysis.

document: The Samsung Galaxy Note 7, unveiled in August 2016, was a highly anticipated Android phablet. It introduced several new features to the Galaxy Note series, such as a dual-sided curved display, an iris recognition system, and a USB-C port. Building upon the success of its predecessor, the Galaxy Note 5, the Note 7 also inherited improvements from the Galaxy S7, including expandable storage and IP68 water resistance. One interesting marketing choice Samsung made was branding this device as the "7th" in the series instead of "6th" to avoid consumer confusion with the flagship Galaxy S7 released in the same year. Unfortunately, the Note 7 was discontinued due to safety concerns regarding its battery overheating issues.
noref_document: The Samsung Galaxy Note 7 was a flagship smartphone released by Samsung in 2016. It was highly anticipated due to its innovative features and sleek design. However, the device gained notorious attention for its faulty battery, which led to numerous incidents of explosions and fires. As a result, Samsung had to recall and eventually discontinue the product. This incident served as a cautionary tale for manufacturers, highlighting the importance of rigorous quality control and ensuring the safety of consumers.
summary:
The Samsung Galaxy Note 7 is a discontinued Android-based phablet designed, developed, produced and marketed by Samsung Electronics. Unveiled on 2 August 2016, it was officially released on 19 August 2016 as a successor to the Galaxy Note 5. It is Samsung's first phone with a USB-C connector, and the last phone in the Galaxy Note series to have a physical home button. Although it is the sixth main device in the Galaxy Note series, Samsung branded its series number as "7" instead of "6" so consumers would not perceive it as being inferior to the flagship Samsung Galaxy S7, and to prevent confusion about the order of release due to the same release year (2016).
The Galaxy Note 7 is an evolution of the Galaxy Note 5 that inherited hardware components and improvements from the Galaxy S7, including the restoration of expandable storage and IP68 water resistance, and new features such as a dual-sided curved display, support for high-dynamic-range (HDR) color, improvements to the bundled stylus and new software features which utilize it, an iris recognition system, and a USB-C port.

As a result, Samsung had to recall and eventually discontinue the product. This incident served as a cautionary tale for manufacturers, highlighting the importance of rigorous quality control and ensuring the safety of consumers.
summary:
The Samsung Galaxy Note 7 is a discontinued Android-based phablet designed, developed, produced and marketed by Samsung Electronics. Unveiled on 2 August 2016, it was officially released on 19 August 2016 as a successor to the Galaxy Note 5. It is Samsung's first phone with a USB-C connector, and the last phone in the Galaxy Note series to have a physical home button. Although it is the sixth main device in the Galaxy Note series, Samsung branded its series number as "7" instead of "6" so consumers would not perceive it as being inferior to the flagship Samsung Galaxy S7, and to prevent confusion about the order of release due to the same release year (2016).
The Galaxy Note 7 is an evolution of the Galaxy Note 5 that inherited hardware components and improvements from the Galaxy S7, including the restoration of expandable storage and IP68 water resistance, and new features such as a dual-sided curved display, support for high-dynamic-range (HDR) color, improvements to the bundled stylus and new software features which utilize it, an iris recognition system, and a USB-C port.

document: The Samsung Galaxy Note 7, unveiled in August 2016, was a highly anticipated Android phablet. It introduced several new features to the Galaxy Note series, such as a dual-sided curved display, an iris recognition system, and a USB-C port. Building upon the success of its predecessor, the Galaxy Note 5, the Note 7 also inherited improvements from the Galaxy S7, including expandable storage and IP68 water resistance. One interesting marketing choice Samsung made was branding this device as the "7th" in the series instead of "6th" to avoid consumer confusion with the flagship Galaxy S7 released in the same year. Unfortunately, the Note 7 was discontinued due to safety concerns regarding its battery overheating issues.

document: Voyager 1, a space probe launched by NASA on September 5, 1977, is currently the most distant human-made object from Earth. Having operated for an impressive 46 years and 14 days, it forms a crucial part of the Voyager program designed to explore the outer Solar System and interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. Communicating through the NASA Deep Space Network, Voyager 1 receives routine commands and transmits valuable data back to Earth. At a distance of 161 AU (24 billion km; 15 billion mi) from Earth as of August 2023, this remarkable probe has completed flybys of Jupiter, Saturn, and Saturn's largest moon, Titan. The choice to prioritize the Titan flyby over Pluto was made due to the former's substantial atmosphere, making it an intriguing subject for exploration.
noref_document: Voyager 1 is a space probe launched by NASA in 1977 to study the outer Solar System and beyond. It became the first human-made object to reach interstellar space in 2012, marking a significant milestone in space exploration. Voyager 1 has provided valuable data and images of Jupiter, Saturn, and their moons, giving scientists a better understanding of these distant worlds. It continues to transmit data back to Earth, despite being over 14 billion miles away from the planet. The Voyager 1 mission has inspired awe and curiosity, pushing the boundaries of what we can achieve in space exploration.
summary: Voyager 1 is a space probe launched by NASA on September 5, 1977, as part of the Voyager program to study the outer Solar System and interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. Launched 16 days after its twin Voyager 2, Voyager 1 has been operating for 46 years and 14 days as of September 19, 2023 UTC [refresh]. It communicates through the NASA Deep Space Network to receive routine commands and to transmit data to Earth. Real-time distance and velocity data is provided by NASA and JPL. At a distance of 161 AU (24 billion km; 15 billion mi) from Earth as of August 2023, it is the most distant human-made object from Earth.The probe made flybys of Jupiter, Saturn, and Saturn's largest moon, Titan. NASA had a choice of either doing a Pluto or Titan flyby; exploration of the moon took priority because it was known to have a substantial atmosphere.

document: Voyager 2, a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, embarked on an extraordinary journey to explore the outer planets and venture beyond the boundaries of the Sun's heliosphere into interstellar space. Alongside its twin, Voyager 1, it was a part of the ambitious Voyager program. Unlike its sibling, Voyager 2 took a longer trajectory to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but was rewarded with further encounters with the ice giants Uranus and Neptune. Demonstrating its incredible capability, Voyager 2 achieved Solar escape velocity, becoming the third of only five spacecraft to venture beyond the boundaries of our Solar System. During its mission, Voyager 2 successfully fulfilled its primary objective, providing valuable insights into the Jovian, Saturnian, Uranian, and Neptunian systems, unveiling captivating discoveries about these distant worlds.

document: Pioneer 10, the NASA space probe launched in 1972, holds the prestigious title of completing the first-ever mission to the planet Jupiter. Not only that, but this remarkable spacecraft also became the pioneer among five planetary probes and eleven artificial objects to successfully attain the escape velocity necessary to venture beyond the boundaries of our Solar System. With its roots at the NASA Ames Research Center in California, Pioneer 10 was specially crafted by TRW Inc. The spacecraft's design revolved around a hexagonal bus, hosting an impressive parabolic dish high-gain antenna measuring a diameter of 2.74 meters (9 ft 0 in). Thanks to its spin stabilization mechanism centered on the axis of the antenna, Pioneer 10 embarked on an extraordinary journey of space exploration.
noref_document: Pioneer 10, launched in 1972, was the first spacecraft to travel through the asteroid belt and study Jupiter up close. This pioneering space probe gathered valuable data about the largest planet in our solar system, including its atmosphere, magnetic field, and moons. It also provided us with stunning close-up images of Jupiter, providing scientists with crucial insights about its turbulent atmosphere and stormy surface. Although it has since ceased communication with Earth, Pioneer 10 remains a testament to human curiosity and exploration, paving the way for future deep space missions.
summary:
Pioneer 10 (originally designated Pioneer F) is a NASA space probe launched in 1972 that completed the first mission to the planet Jupiter. Pioneer 10 became the first of five planetary probes and 11 artificial objects to achieve the escape velocity needed to leave the Solar System. This space exploration project was conducted by the NASA Ames Research Center in California. The space probe was manufactured by TRW Inc.
Pioneer 10 was assembled around a hexagonal bus with a 2.74-meter (9 ft 0 in) diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna, and the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of the antenna.

document: Mariner 4, also known as Mariner-Mars 1964, was a pioneering spacecraft in the field of planetary exploration. Launched on November 28, 1964, its primary objective was to conduct closeup scientific observations of Mars and transmit them back to Earth. This mission marked a significant milestone as it became the first spacecraft to successfully flyby Mars, capturing and returning the first close-up images of the Martian surface. These images were a game-changer, revealing a cratered and lifeless planet, thus reshaping the scientific community's understanding of Mars' potential for sustaining life. In addition to image capture, Mariner 4 also aimed to measure fields and particles in interplanetary space near Mars, providing valuable insights and engineering knowledge for future long-duration interplanetary flights.
noref_document: Mariner 4 was an interplanetary space probe launched by NASA in 1964. Its main objective was to conduct a flyby mission of the planet Mars and gather information about its atmosphere and surface. Mariner 4 successfully obtained the first close-up images of Mars, revealing a diverse landscape characterized by impact craters, valleys, and volcanic features. These images provided valuable insights into the geology of the Red Planet, leading to a better understanding of its evolution and history. Mariner 4's mission marked a significant milestone in the exploration of Mars and paved the way for future missions to this enigmatic planet.
summary: Mariner 4 (together with Mariner 3 known as Mariner-Mars 1964) was the fourth in a series of spacecraft intended for planetary exploration in a flyby mode. It was designed to conduct closeup scientific observations of Mars and to transmit these observations to Earth. Launched on November 28, 1964, Mariner 4 performed the first successful flyby of the planet Mars, returning the first close-up pictures of the Martian surface. It captured the first images of another planet ever returned from deep space; their depiction of a cratered, dead planet largely changed the scientific community's view of life on Mars.  Other mission objectives were to perform field and particle measurements in interplanetary space in the vicinity of Mars and to provide experience in and knowledge of the engineering capabilities for interplanetary flights of long duration.

document: The Galileo spacecraft, named after the renowned Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, was an American robotic space probe that embarked on a remarkable mission to study the planet Jupiter and its moons. Delivered into Earth's orbit on October 18, 1989, by the Space Shuttle Atlantis during STS-34, Galileo made its way to Jupiter on December 7, 1995, becoming the first spacecraft to orbit an outer planet. This remarkable feat was achieved after flybys of Venus and Earth, utilizing gravitational assist. The Galileo spacecraft consisted of an orbiter, responsible for collecting data on Jupiter and its moons, and an entry probe. Built by the Jet Propulsion Laboratory and managed by NASA, the Galileo program also relied on the propulsion module supplied by Germany's Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm and the atmospheric probe built by Hughes Aircraft Company, with management by NASA's Ames Research Center. Along its journey, Galileo also studied the asteroids Gaspra and Ida, providing valuable insights into the mysteries of our solar system.
noref_document: The Galileo spacecraft was a renowned mission by NASA to explore the Jupiter system. Launched in 1989, it entered orbit around Jupiter in 1995, becoming the first spacecraft to do so. Galileo was equipped with various scientific instruments, including a camera, spectrometer, and magnetometer, which helped to gather data on Jupiter, its moons, and the planet's magnetosphere. Over the course of its mission, Galileo revealed a wealth of information, including the discovery of water vapor plumes on Jupiter's moon Europa, evidence of a subsurface ocean, and insights into the planet's powerful magnetic field. The spacecraft also provided detailed images of Jupiter's atmosphere, capturing stunning views of its bands, vortices, and the iconic Great Red Spot. Despite experiencing technical challenges and limitations, Galileo's mission lasted until 2003, offering valuable scientific discoveries and expanding our understanding of the giant planet and its surroundings.

document: Voyager 2, a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, embarked on an extraordinary mission to explore the outer planets and venture into interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. As part of the Voyager program, it was sent off 16 days ahead of its twin, Voyager 1, following a trajectory that required more time to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but allowed for unprecedented encounters with ice giants Uranus and Neptune. In fact, Voyager 2 still holds the distinction of being the only spacecraft to have ever visited these mesmerizing ice giant planets. As a pioneer in space exploration, Voyager 2 became the third out of five spacecraft to achieve Solar escape velocity, granting it the ability to leave our Solar System. Throughout its journey, Voyager 2 successfully completed its primary mission, visiting the Jovian system in 1979, the Saturnian system in 1981, the Uranian system in 1986, and accomplished its grand finale by exploring the Neptunian system in 1989. Its remarkable accomplishments have provided us with invaluable knowledge about the outer reaches of our celestial neighborhood.
noref_document: Voyager 2 is a space probe launched by NASA in 1977 as part of the Voyager program. It is the only spacecraft to have visited all four of the outer planets of the solar system – Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune – and is currently the second furthest human-made object from Earth, after Voyager 1. Voyager 2 has provided scientists with a wealth of invaluable data and stunning images of these distant worlds, revolutionizing our understanding of the outer solar system. This remarkable spacecraft continues to operate and send back valuable information, even after more than four decades of its launch.

document: Voyager 2, a space probe launched by NASA on August 20, 1977, embarked on an extraordinary mission to explore the outer planets and venture into interstellar space beyond the Sun's heliosphere. As part of the Voyager program, it was sent off 16 days ahead of its twin, Voyager 1, following a trajectory that required more time to reach gas giants Jupiter and Saturn but allowed for unprecedented encounters with ice giants Uranus and Neptune. In fact, Voyager 2 still holds the distinction of being the only spacecraft to have ever visited these mesmerizing ice giant planets. As a pioneer in space exploration, Voyager 2 became the third out of five spacecraft to achieve Solar escape velocity, granting it the ability to leave our Solar System. Throughout its journey, Voyager 2 successfully completed its primary mission, visiting the Jovian system in 1979, the Saturnian system in 1981, the Uranian system in 1986, and accomplished its grand finale by exploring the Neptunian system in 1989. Its remarkable accomplishments have provided us with invaluable knowledge about the outer reaches of our celestial neighborhood.
noref_document: Voyager 2 is a space probe launched by NASA in 1977 as part of the Voyager program. It is the only spacecraft to have visited all four of the outer planets of the solar system – Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus, and Neptune – and is currently the second furthest human-made object from Earth, after Voyager 1. Voyager 2 has provided scientists with a wealth of invaluable data and stunning images of these distant worlds, revolutionizing our understanding of the outer solar system. This remarkable spacecraft continues to operate and send back valuable information, even after more than four decades of its launch.

document: The 2016 United States presidential election will forever be remembered as a historic moment in American politics. Against all odds, Republican candidate Donald Trump and his running mate Mike Pence secured a victory over the Democratic ticket of Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine. The election itself was filled with surprises and controversies, with Trump's unconventional campaign style attracting significant media attention. Utilizing a right-wing populist and nationalist platform, Trump promised to "Make America Great Again" and criticized issues such as political correctness, illegal immigration, and free-trade agreements. Clinton, on the other hand, became the first female presidential nominee of a major American political party, solidifying her position as a trailblazer in American history. The election showcased the divisions within the country and marked the end of President Barack Obama's tenure, as he was ineligible to pursue a third term according to the Twenty-second Amendment to the US Constitution. Overall, the 2016 presidential election left an indelible mark on the nation's political landscape.
noref_document: The 2016 United States presidential election was a historic event that captured the attention of the nation and the world. This election, which took place on November 8, 2016, saw Republican candidate Donald J. Trump face off against Democratic candidate Hillary Clinton. The campaign was marked by intense debates, controversies, and a high level of voter engagement. Ultimately, Donald Trump emerged victorious, securing the presidency and becoming the 45th President of the United States. This election will be remembered for its unprecedented nature, as it highlighted the deep divisions within the country and the significance of political participation.
summary: The 2016 United States presidential election was the 58th quadrennial presidential election, held on Tuesday, November 8, 2016. The Republican ticket of businessman Donald Trump and Indiana governor Mike Pence defeated the Democratic ticket of former secretary of state and First Lady of the United States Hillary Clinton and the junior senator from Virginia Tim Kaine, in what was considered one of the biggest political upsets in American history.Incumbent Democratic President Barack Obama was ineligible to pursue a third term due to the term limits established by the Twenty-second Amendment to the US Constitution. Clinton secured the nomination over U.S. senator Bernie Sanders in the Democratic primary and became the first female presidential nominee of a major American political party. Trump emerged as his party's front-runner amidst a wide field of candidates in the Republican primary, defeating U.S. senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, governors John Kasich and Jeb Bush, among other candidates. Trump's right-wing populist, nationalist campaign, which promised to "Make America Great Again" and opposed political correctness, illegal immigration, and many United States free-trade agreements garnered extensive free media coverage due to Trump's inflammatory comments.

Trump emerged as his party's front-runner amidst a wide field of candidates in the Republican primary, defeating U.S. senators Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio, governors John Kasich and Jeb Bush, among other candidates. Trump's right-wing populist, nationalist campaign, which promised to "Make America Great Again" and opposed political correctness, illegal immigration, and many United States free-trade agreements garnered extensive free media coverage due to Trump's inflammatory comments.

document: The 2016 United States presidential election will forever be remembered as a historic moment in American politics. Against all odds, Republican candidate Donald Trump and his running mate Mike Pence secured a victory over the Democratic ticket of Hillary Clinton and Tim Kaine. The election itself was filled with surprises and controversies, with Trump's unconventional campaign style attracting significant media attention. Overall, the 2016 presidential election left an indelible mark on the nation's political landscape.

document: Expo 2010 Shanghai China, held from 1 May to 31 October 2010, was a remarkable World Expo that took place on both banks of the Huangpu River in Shanghai, China. With the theme "Better City – Better Life," it symbolized Shanghai's emergence as a leading global city in the 21st century. The iconic Expo emblem featured the Chinese character 世 ('world') creatively transformed to represent three individuals, signifying unity and collaboration, alongside the year 2010. The theme of Expo 2010 was "Better City, Better Life," focusing on sustainable urban development. The event showcased various pavilions, each representing different nations, showcasing their cultural heritage, technological advancements, and innovative designs. Expo 2010 aimed to promote cultural exchange, economic cooperation, and urban sustainability, leaving a lasting impact on Shanghai's urban landscape.

The theme of the exposition was "Better City – Better Life" and signifies Shanghai's new status in the 21st century as the "next great world city". It had the largest number of countries participating and was the most expensive Expo in the history of the world's fairs.

document: The highly anticipated wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton took place on April 29, 2011, at the iconic Westminster Abbey in London, England. As second in line to the British throne, Prince William's marriage ceremony with Middleton garnered worldwide attention and interest. The couple's relationship had blossomed since 2003, adding an element of long-lasting commitment to their union. The service was officiated by John Hall, Dean of Westminster, while Rowan Williams, the then Archbishop of Canterbury, conducted the marriage proceedings. The sermon was delivered by Richard Chartres, the then Bishop of London, and a reading was given by Catherine's brother, James. Prince Harry took on the role of William's best man, while the bride's sister, Pippa, assumed the honor of being the maid of honor. The wedding marked a momentous occasion, capturing the hearts and imaginations of people across the globe.
noref_document: The wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton, also known as the royal wedding, took place on April 29, 2011. It was a highly anticipated event that captured the attention of people worldwide. The ceremony was held at Westminster Abbey in London and was attended by numerous dignitaries, celebrities, and members of the British royal family. The beautiful bride, Catherine Middleton, wore a stunning gown designed by Sarah Burton for Alexander McQueen. The wedding was a lavish affair, with intricate floral arrangements and a grand procession. Millions of people tuned in to watch the televised event, as the couple exchanged vows and embarked on their journey as husband and wife. It was a momentous occasion that marked a new chapter in the British monarchy and captivated audiences around the globe.
summary:
The wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton took place on Friday, 29 April 2011 at Westminster Abbey in London, England. The groom was second in the line of succession to the British throne. The couple had been in a relationship since 2003.
John Hall, Dean of Westminster, presided at the service; Rowan Williams, the then Archbishop of Canterbury, conducted the marriage; Richard Chartres, the then Bishop of London, preached the sermon; and a reading was given by the bride's brother, James. William's best man was his brother, Prince Harry, while the bride's sister, Pippa, was the maid of honour.

summary:

document: Pioneer 10, a NASA space probe launched in 1972 by the Ames Research Center in California, embarked on a historic mission to Jupiter. Not only did it successfully complete this mission, but it also achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the first artificial object to reach the escape velocity required to exit the Solar System. This groundbreaking exploration initiative involved the assembly of Pioneer 10 around a hexagonal bus, featuring a 2.74-meter diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna. To maintain stability during its journey, the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of this antenna. Manufactured by TRW Inc., Pioneer 10 played an instrumental role in advancing our understanding of the outer reaches of the cosmos.
noref_document: Pioneer 10 was a NASA spacecraft that marked a significant milestone in space exploration. Launched on March 2, 1972, Pioneer 10 became the first spacecraft to traverse the asteroid belt and successfully reach Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system. Its primary mission was to gather scientific data about Jupiter and its environment, as well as test the limits of human-made technology in deep space. Equipped with a range of instruments, including cameras and particle detectors, Pioneer 10 provided valuable insights into the Jovian atmosphere, magnetic field, and radiation belts. After completing its mission at Jupiter, Pioneer 10 continued its pioneering journey, becoming the first man-made object to venture out of our solar system and into interstellar space. Although communication with Pioneer 10 was eventually lost in 2003, its legacy lives on as a testament to human curiosity and the boundless possibilities of space exploration.
summary:
Pioneer 10 (originally designated Pioneer F) is a NASA space probe launched in 1972 that completed the first mission to the planet Jupiter. Pioneer 10 became the first of five planetary probes and 11 artificial objects to achieve the escape velocity needed to leave the Solar System. This space exploration project was conducted by the NASA Ames Research Center in California. The space probe was manufactured by TRW Inc.
Pioneer 10 was assembled around a hexagonal bus with a 2.74-meter (9 ft 0 in) diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna, and the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of the antenna.

document: Pioneer 10, a NASA space probe launched in 1972 by the Ames Research Center in California, embarked on a historic mission to Jupiter. Not only did it successfully complete this mission, but it also achieved a remarkable feat by becoming the first artificial object to reach the escape velocity required to exit the Solar System. This groundbreaking exploration initiative involved the assembly of Pioneer 10 around a hexagonal bus, featuring a 2.74-meter diameter parabolic dish high-gain antenna. To maintain stability during its journey, the spacecraft was spin stabilized around the axis of this antenna. Manufactured by TRW Inc., Pioneer 10 played an instrumental role in advancing our understanding of the outer reaches of the cosmos.
noref_document: Pioneer 10 was a NASA spacecraft that marked a significant milestone in space exploration. Launched on March 2, 1972, Pioneer 10 became the first spacecraft to traverse the asteroid belt and successfully reach Jupiter, the largest planet in our solar system. Its primary mission was to gather scientific data about Jupiter and its environment, as well as test the limits of human-made technology in deep space. Equipped with a range of instruments, including cameras and particle detectors, Pioneer 10 provided valuable insights into the Jovian atmosphere, magnetic field, and radiation belts. After completing its mission at Jupiter, Pioneer 10 continued its pioneering journey, becoming the first man-made object to venture out of our solar system and into interstellar space. Although communication with Pioneer 10 was eventually lost in 2003, its legacy lives on as a testament to human curiosity and the boundless possibilities of space exploration.

document: Mariner 4, a spacecraft launched on November 28, 1964, marked a significant milestone in planetary exploration by performing the first successful flyby of Mars. Its primary objective was to conduct closeup scientific observations of the planet, capturing and transmitting these observations back to Earth. Mariner 4 revolutionized our understanding of Mars, as it returned the first close-up pictures ever taken of the Martian surface. These images depicted a cratered, lifeless landscape, challenging the scientific community's previous perceptions of the possibility of life on the planet. Additionally, Mariner 4 aimed to measure fields and particles in interplanetary space near Mars, while also providing valuable knowledge and expertise in long-duration interplanetary flights.
noref_document: Mariner 4 was a NASA spacecraft that made history by becoming the first successful mission to Mars. Launched on November 28, 1964, Mariner 4 embarked on a 228-day voyage to the red planet, capturing images and collecting valuable scientific data along the way. On July 14, 1965, it performed a flyby of Mars, coming within 6,118 miles of its surface. The images transmitted back to Earth provided the first close-up view of Mars, revealing a barren landscape with a crater-pocked surface. Mariner 4 revolutionized our understanding of the red planet and paved the way for future missions to explore Mars in greater detail.
summary: Mariner 4 (together with Mariner 3 known as Mariner-Mars 1964) was the fourth in a series of spacecraft intended for planetary exploration in a flyby mode. It was designed to conduct closeup scientific observations of Mars and to transmit these observations to Earth. Launched on November 28, 1964, Mariner 4 performed the first successful flyby of the planet Mars, returning the first close-up pictures of the Martian surface. It captured the first images of another planet ever returned from deep space; their depiction of a cratered, dead planet largely changed the scientific community's view of life on Mars.  Other mission objectives were to perform field and particle measurements in interplanetary space in the vicinity of Mars and to provide experience in and knowledge of the engineering capabilities for interplanetary flights of long duration.

document: Galileo, named after the famous Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, was an American robotic space probe that explored the mysteries of the largest planet in our solar system, Jupiter, along with its moons and even some asteroids. This groundbreaking spacecraft had two main components, an orbiter and an entry probe. Launched into Earth's orbit on October 18, 1989, by the Space Shuttle Atlantis as part of the STS-34 mission, Galileo utilized gravitational assists from Venus and Earth to reach Jupiter, eventually becoming the first spacecraft to ever orbit an outer planet. The esteemed Jet Propulsion Laboratory was responsible for building the Galileo spacecraft and managing the entire program for NASA. The propulsion module, essential for the spacecraft's movement, was supplied by Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm, a company based in West Germany. Additionally, the atmospheric probe, a crucial aspect of Galileo's mission, was skillfully constructed by Hughes Aircraft Company and managed by NASA's Ames Research Center.
noref_document: The Galileo spacecraft was a NASA mission that aimed to study Jupiter and its moons. Launched in 1989, Galileo conducted a series of flybys of asteroids on its way to Jupiter. Once in the vicinity of the gas giant, Galileo began its extensive study of the planet and its moons, taking detailed images and collecting data on their compositions and atmospheres. The spacecraft also deployed a probe called the Galileo Probe, which descended into Jupiter's atmosphere and transmitted valuable information back to Earth. Galileo's mission provided significant insights into the Jovian system, and its data greatly contributed to our understanding of the largest planet in our solar system.
summary: Galileo was an American robotic space probe that studied the planet Jupiter and its moons, as well as the asteroids Gaspra and Ida. Named after the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, it consisted of an orbiter and an entry probe. It was delivered into Earth orbit on October 18, 1989, by Space Shuttle Atlantis , during STS-34. Galileo arrived at Jupiter on December 7, 1995, after gravitational assist flybys of Venus and Earth, and became the first spacecraft to orbit an outer planet.The Jet Propulsion Laboratory built the Galileo spacecraft and managed the Galileo program for NASA. West Germany's Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm supplied the propulsion module. NASA's Ames Research Center managed the atmospheric probe, which was built by Hughes Aircraft Company.

summary: Galileo was an American robotic space probe that studied the planet Jupiter and its moons, as well as the asteroids Gaspra and Ida. Named after the Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, it consisted of an orbiter and an entry probe. It was delivered into Earth orbit on October 18, 1989, by Space Shuttle Atlantis , during STS-34. Galileo arrived at Jupiter on December 7, 1995, after gravitational assist flybys of Venus and Earth, and became the first spacecraft to orbit an outer planet.The Jet Propulsion Laboratory built the Galileo spacecraft and managed the Galileo program for NASA. West Germany's Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm supplied the propulsion module. NASA's Ames Research Center managed the atmospheric probe, which was built by Hughes Aircraft Company.

document: Galileo, named after the famous Italian astronomer Galileo Galilei, was an American robotic space probe that explored the mysteries of the largest planet in our solar system, Jupiter, along with its moons and even some asteroids. This groundbreaking spacecraft had two main components, an orbiter and an entry probe. Launched into Earth's orbit on October 18, 1989, by the Space Shuttle Atlantis as part of the STS-34 mission, Galileo utilized gravitational assists from Venus and Earth to reach Jupiter, eventually becoming the first spacecraft to ever orbit an outer planet. The esteemed Jet Propulsion Laboratory was responsible for building the Galileo spacecraft and managing the entire program for NASA. The propulsion module, essential for the spacecraft's movement, was supplied by Messerschmitt-Bölkow-Blohm, a company based in West Germany. Additionally, the atmospheric probe, a crucial aspect of Galileo's mission, was skillfully constructed by Hughes Aircraft Company and managed by NASA's Ames Research Center.

document: Stardust, a 385-kilogram robotic space probe launched by NASA in 1999, embarked on an extraordinary mission that revolutionized our understanding of comets and cosmic dust. Its primary objective was to collect dust samples from the coma of comet Wild 2 and cosmic dust, and bring them back to Earth for analysis. This groundbreaking endeavor marked the first-ever sample return mission of its kind. Along its journey to comet Wild 2, Stardust also made a significant detour to study the asteroid 5535 Annefrank. After a successful completion of its primary mission in January 2006, the spacecraft embarked on a mission extension known as NExT. This exciting continuation culminated in 2011 when Stardust intercepted comet Tempel 1, a small Solar System body that had previously been visited by the Deep Impact mission in 2005. Through its remarkable voyages and invaluable samples, Stardust expanded our knowledge of celestial bodies and contributed to numerous scientific breakthroughs.
noref_document: The Stardust spacecraft was a NASA mission designed to study the composition of comets and collect samples of dust from a comet's coma. Launched in 1999, Stardust traveled to the comet Wild 2 and successfully captured cometary particles, becoming the first spacecraft to bring samples from a comet back to Earth. In addition to its primary mission, Stardust also collected interstellar dust grains during its journey. The spacecraft returned to Earth in 2006, delivering its precious cargo to scientists who continue to analyze and study these cosmic samples, providing valuable insights into the origins and nature of our solar system.

document: The 2008 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXIX Olympiad, were a remarkable international multisport event held in Beijing, China, from 8 to 24 August 2008. It was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games and marked the third occurrence of the Summer Olympics in East Asia. With 10,942 athletes representing 204 National Olympic Committees, the event showcased the talents and skills of athletes competing in 28 sports and 302 events, one more than the previous Olympics. Beijing's successful bid to host the Games was announced on 13 July 2001 after winning the majority of votes from the International Olympic Committee. This historical event contributed to the rich Olympic heritage of both China and East Asia, while also highlighting the global unity and celebration of sport.
noref_document: The 2008 Summer Olympics, officially known as the Games of the XXIX Olympiad, was a major international multi-sport event held in Beijing, China. It kicked off on August 8, 2008, and came to an end on August 24, 2008. The Beijing Games showcased various sports competitions and hosted a record-breaking 11,028 athletes from 204 National Olympic Committees. The event took place in impressive venues, including the Bird's Nest stadium and the Water Cube aquatics center. These Olympics attracted worldwide attention, not only due to the outstanding performances of athletes like Michael Phelps, but also because of China's rich cultural heritage and technological innovations on display during the opening and closing ceremonies. The 2008 Summer Olympics left a lasting legacy for Beijing and highlighted the country's ability to host major international events.
summary:
The 2008 Summer Olympics (Chinese: 2008年夏季奥运会; pinyin: Èr Líng Líng Bā Nián Xiàjì Àoyùnhuì), officially the Games of the XXIX Olympiad (Chinese: 第二十九届夏季奥林匹克运动会; pinyin: Dì Èrshíjiǔ Jiè Xiàjì Àolínpǐkè Yùndònghuì) and also known as Beijing 2008 (Chinese: 北京2008; pinyin: Běijīng èr líng líng bā), were an international multisport event held from 8 to 24 August 2008, in Beijing, China. A total of 10,942 athletes from 204 National Olympic Committees (NOCs) competed in 28 sports and 302 events, one event more than those scheduled for the 2004 Summer Olympics. This was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games, and the third time the Summer Olympic Games had been held in East Asia, following the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. These were also the second Summer Olympic Games to be held in a communist state, the first being the 1980 Summer Olympics in the Soviet Union (with venues in Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, and Estonia).
Beijing was awarded the 2008 Games over four competitors on 13 July 2001, having won a majority of votes from members of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) after two rounds of voting.

The 2008 Summer Olympics (Chinese: 2008年夏季奥运会; pinyin: Èr Líng Líng Bā Nián Xiàjì Àoyùnhuì), officially the Games of the XXIX Olympiad (Chinese: 第二十九届夏季奥林匹克运动会; pinyin: Dì Èrshíjiǔ Jiè Xiàjì Àolínpǐkè Yùndònghuì) and also known as Beijing 2008 (Chinese: 北京2008; pinyin: Běijīng èr líng líng bā), were an international multisport event held from 8 to 24 August 2008, in Beijing, China. A total of 10,942 athletes from 204 National Olympic Committees (NOCs) competed in 28 sports and 302 events, one event more than those scheduled for the 2004 Summer Olympics. This was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games, and the third time the Summer Olympic Games had been held in East Asia, following the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. These were also the second Summer Olympic Games to be held in a communist state, the first being the 1980 Summer Olympics in the Soviet Union (with venues in Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, and Estonia).
Beijing was awarded the 2008 Games over four competitors on 13 July 2001, having won a majority of votes from members of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) after two rounds of voting.

The 2008 Summer Olympics (Chinese: 2008年夏季奥运会; pinyin: Èr Líng Líng Bā Nián Xiàjì Àoyùnhuì), officially the Games of the XXIX Olympiad (Chinese: 第二十九届夏季奥林匹克运动会; pinyin: Dì Èrshíjiǔ Jiè Xiàjì Àolínpǐkè Yùndònghuì) and also known as Beijing 2008 (Chinese: 北京2008; pinyin: Běijīng èr líng líng bā), were an international multisport event held from 8 to 24 August 2008, in Beijing, China. A total of 10,942 athletes from 204 National Olympic Committees (NOCs) competed in 28 sports and 302 events, one event more than those scheduled for the 2004 Summer Olympics. This was the first time China had hosted the Olympic Games, and the third time the Summer Olympic Games had been held in East Asia, following the 1964 Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea. These were also the second Summer Olympic Games to be held in a communist state, the first being the 1980 Summer Olympics in the Soviet Union (with venues in Russia, Ukraine, Byelorussia, and Estonia).
